page.lettertext:
S
r
. By theise inclosed you may percieve that one
George [Bornstroi]
a Captaine of those Countries pretending
some great service done for h
r
Ma
tye
hath bene a suitor heere
for recompence. In w
ch
cause that you maye be through
ly
informed, I have sent you his Remonstraunce togeather wit
h
certaine Apostilles thereunto, and his acquittance for the recei
pt
of such s
o
mes of monye as have beene bestowed upon him: whereby
maye appeare that his rewarde from hir Ma
tye
hath in all respect
beene sufficient for his service. Notw
th
standing because the States
to ease themselves of Charge have under hand directed him
hither: yo
w
maye likewise as you see occasion rec
o
mend him
in generall termes back againe unto them, who first sett him
on worcke, and from whome it seemeth he hath received nothing:
whereas by hir Ma
tye
he hath bene most bountifullye rewarded,
whome yet the service did not principallye concerne.
Referring you therefore to theise pieces hereinclosed, whereout
you maye understand the particuler Course of this whole
matter, I most hartelye c
o
mitt you to god. At the
Courte
the i of Maye. 1590
Your assured loving frend William Burghley
